title: The Futurists - EPS_296: WHAT IS JONY IVE COOKING? With Brett King and Robert Tercek

rawLines.text: This week on the
futurists, Rob and Brett are back.
In the very near future, it's going to
be agent to agent communication when no
one's going to be using search. Humans
won't be using search. Yeah. Uh agents
will be doing all the discovery. They'll
be doing all the processing. They'll be
looking after, you know, and and this
whole notion of search optimization and
creating these, you know, link farms.
It's all gone. All going to go away.
[Music]
Hey everybody, welcome back to the
futurist. I'm Rob Turszig with my buddy
co-host Brett King. Brett, hi. Great to
connect with you. Hey man. Yeah, it's
been
I I was in uh Khan for the film
festival. It's like when this goes to
air, it's going to be a week week after.
But um and then uh I had two events on
the same day, one virtual and one um you
know on stage and I had to literally get
off stage and had 4 minutes to get into
my hotel room to do the second event and
then immediately after that got on a
plane and came here to UAE where I
opened the keynote for the government
digital readiness retreat uh this
morning. So, it's been a pretty wild few
days, my my friend. In intense. I I
know. I get your dispatches when you're
going from place to place. Um, and uh
and so I kind of feel like I'm
vicariously traveling along with you.
Hey, tell me about some insights from uh
from the UAE. So, you've been spending
quite a bit of time in Dubai and in the
region. So, tell me what's happening
there. So, I'm actually working with the
prime minister's office as as a
futurist, resident futurist, which is
pretty cool. Um, you know, I I've
actually thought about this like if
there were um three, you know, let's say
the top three uh governments in the
world that a futurist would be welcomed
to today. Um, my guess is it would
probably be China number one, although I
don't have the language competency for
that, but uh, you know, some of our
Chinese futurist friends might. Um, then
I would say UAE and Saudi are definitely
right up there. um you know we had a
delegation from Singapore at this event
today and they used to host people from
the UAE in Singapore all the time. Now
it's the opposite. Now, Singaporeans are
coming to the UAE to learn about uh
future readiness. And there was a um
hearing not that long ago where uh
representative of the US government was
talking about how the US should be able
to do what Abu Dhabi can do in terms of
like uh you know, immigration handling
at the airport and stuff like that. But
it's really interesting to see the sort
of future readiness uh culture that is
appearing here. Um the embracing of
this. there's no um defensiveness of
like traditional incumbent sectors. It's
all like uh there's this culture of
embracing change. So, it's pretty
interesting environment to come into now
because you know as a futurist I find
this is pushing me even harder to be on
my game and to be researching um you
know the the latest trends and
developments and things like that. But I
did want to I did I did you see the news
about Open AI's uh big data center
they're launching in the UAE? So OpenAI
has been generating a lot of news. Tell
us what's happening in the UAE. Give us
give us the update from from the
Emirates. So they just signed a deal to
launch a major data center AI data
center in the UAE and it's the largest
data center. It's going to be um they
say it's uh I I can't remember the um um
the geography but that that they compare
it to but it's a 5 gawatt data center.
So this is really interesting is now
we're measuring data centers by the
amount of you know electricity they
consume.
Um yeah so it's a 5 G data center. It's
going to cost a h 100red billion um but
bringing in $40 billion annually. Uh
it's a it's a it's a pretty big deal.
Any insight on whether that'll be
powered by renewable energy? They
probably haven't disclosed that yet, but
you know, it's kind of a neat concept to
think of taking the radiant energy of
the sun and converting it into
intelligence. If that's a possibility,
that would be a uh that would be kind of
charming. Otherwise, there's no shortage
of fossil fuels in that region. So they
can certainly uh they can certainly burn
some fossils to to run that data center.
There is gen generally a view right now
in terms of um the sort of energy
transformation here that um there is
going to have to be major investment in
solar and alternative uh uh generation
to support these these sorts of efforts
more broadly cuz this is not the only um
thing that's happening on um you know in
the UAE in terms of power demands of
course um you know there's
There's a massive increase for electric
vehicles here. Um, you know, we're
talking about a lot of um, uh, new
energy demands in terms of
transportation
um, and so forth around this, increasing
the metro. There's a new new airport
coming in. So, there's there's a lot of
activity here that's going to require
new energy infrastructure. There there
is a general acceptance this has got to
be net new energy infrastructure um,
that's going to be based on renewable
tech. There's no major um nextg nuclear
here that um for base load that I've
I've seen as yet but of course they are
involved in investing in some sort of
fusion projects. So that could come into
that and um you know they are invested
also in the Chinese efforts for the S
the SMRs the small nuclear reactors and
the thorium um the thorium stuff that's
going on there the molten salt thorium
reactors.
Two interesting things you brought up
there. Uh the first one is is you know
in a way these countries in the Middle
East Saudi Arabia and the UAE but
actually all the countries in that
region are kind of neutral you know they
they work with the west they work with
China they're open uh they seem to be
open to anyone and of course they're
propelled they have a mission right
they're on a mission because they know
that fossil fuel is going to come to an
end at some point and they have to
migrate their entire economy to
something else they can't be entire
dependent on fossil fuel um the other
thing that is worth mentioning here I Uh
the thing I noticed when I was visiting
Dubai and uh and Jordan uh and Oman in
the last year is these are countries
that are not afraid to make a 50-year
investment. You know, they're really
future focused in the sense that they'll
place a bet on infrastructure that is
for 50 years in the future. And the
evidence of that is the existence of
Dubai as a city. Dubai was a little
fishing town. It was a village. Uh now
it's this gigantic thriving metropolis
with a huge port. All those decisions
were made in the 1970s and 80s. uh the
investment came, they structured the
economy, they created incentives and so
forth and attracted the investment. Do
you think that's similar to what's
happening now? Is that a good analogy
for what they're doing with data
centers?
I think I think so. Um but I also think
that you do have you know if you if you
are trying to do investment in AI, you
have some very large um you know
sovereign wealth funds in the region
that are very very interested in
investing in this. So there's a lot of
uh you know foreign investment going
into AI projects. Um you know uh you
have u generally from a regulatory
perspective very friendly regulations
towards this. Obviously there is more
work being done on alignment here but
you know this is I guess the benefit of
the UAE in particular even more so than
than Saudi where they have been fairly
politically neutral. you know,
Switzerland of the Gulf region. Um, and
they do have very good relationships
with the Chinese. They have very good
relationships with the Europeans. They
have good relationships with with the
the US, with India. You know, they have
a lot of uh Indian companies in here.
They're not far from India. You know,
it's only a few hours from here. So when
you look sort of geopolitically they've
got quite a good platform here for um
you know sort of geopolitical stability
um in terms of policy and um you know
generally for for investment both into
the region and investment coming out
from Abu Dhabi and the sovereign wealth
funds into to other regions which of
course uh you know creates stronger
geopolitical relationships as well. To
some extent, this is this reminds me of
the the old phrase from 10 years ago,
data is the new oil. Here you have the
oil the oil countries, the oil nations,
and they're investing in data center. So
like literal manifestation of that
slogan. Uh how critical do you think
data centers are going to be as a value
control point for AI? Is this is this
viewed as like, you know, if you want to
be in the AI game, you've got to have a
massive Stargate style data center or
you can't even compete.
Look, there is obviously with Deep Seek
and other technologies some compression
going on in terms of the models which
could um you know reduce the uh the
compute load for AI over time. But with
the amount of AI that they're looking to
deploy in in the UAE, we're looking to
deploy this for the purpose of
government for um smart city resource
management. So you're looking at
transportation systems, sanitation,
power management, water management and
so forth, supply chain, um looking at
the health care, reinventing the health
care system, the digital twin model,
which of course we've we've talked about
a lot, plus general AI infrastructure.
So I do think you need to start thinking
about um data centers as you would um
you know uh electricity generation or um
you know water treatment plans. I I
think it's just core infrastructure for
even transportation, you know, even like
transportation and supply chain links.
It's essentially it's a key part of the
digital supply chain. Yeah, absolutely.
You need a data center just like you
need a gigantic port uh if you want to
be in the game. Well, this is really
interesting. I mean, we've talked about
this uh before, but UAE is implementing
Chinese tech in the ports here for
automation as well. And we know that
China now has 80% of their ports,
shipping ports, this is that is
automated, fully automated. There are
ports in China that are completely 100%
automated. And if you look at the belt
and road initiative over the last 10
years, what have they been building?
They've been building ports in Africa
and, you know, in Southeast Asia and and
so forth. Um, and those are obvious
targets for this type of level of
automation as well. So, you know, if
you're talking about AI based
infrastructure, we often think about,
you know, what it takes to run these
large LLMs, you know, open AI data
centers for semantic or generative AI.
But from an industrial AI perspective,
you know, that's a quite a different
level of investment. You're really
talking about large scale autonomy in in
the economy which requires many
disparate uh you know technological
advances and changes but it does still
require its core a data center
infrastructure as well. So the power
demands for that are going to go up as
well. So this in a way is a
reinforcement of their current position.
I think when people think about the
Middle East uh and in and UAE, they they
sometimes miss the fact that one of the
largest container ports in the world is
in Dubai. And it's it's actually one of
the reasons why Dubai is so successful.
The the port, I think it's called Abu uh
Abu Jezel, it's managed by DP World,
deep Dubai ports international. And
that's a major supply chain link to
Africa as well. Well, so if you're
shipping goods say from Eastern Asia or
China to Africa, you're most likely to
pass through uh the port in in um in
Dubai. And what you're saying now is
that the data requirements for
automating that. Um you can imagine
almost like you know the the container
ports are switching packets the same way
a network switch packets. The packets on
a container are are the containers those
20ft standard container units that are
on the ships. uh those get switched by
AI just the way same way a packet on a
network might get switched. It's at
least a a reasonable metaphor, but
they're literally building out the data
center. You know, we're kind of
literalizing that metaphor uh by merging
the two things, a data center and a
gigantic container port. Um this is an
interesting notion only in the sense
that in the United States we're so far
behind. Uh you know, here in the United
States, the folks who don't travel, who
don't get a chance to go visit these
places and when they do travel, don't
necessarily do it for business purposes.
So they don't see this perspective that
you see. Um what they might be missing
is that our container ports here are
still largely uh hand you know um manual
require tens of thousands of workers at
the dock and of course right now they're
all freaking out here at the port of LA.
Uh Port of LA and Long Beach can manage
about 30% of the goods coming into the
United States and most of the goods
coming from Asia and those two ports uh
are are nearly idle at this point
because of these silly the tariffs that
have been imposed. Uh so we've got uh
layoffs and you know tens of thousands
of workers whose jobs are in jeopardy at
our ports. Meanwhile, the Chinese have
been focused on automating the ports,
something that has been on the drawing
board for more than 10 years. But during
the pandemic, they really took the lead
in doing this. They had they had to they
had no choice because they had to keep
goods flowing. So they automated their
ports. Here the US uh our unions are
fighting that. Um and they've made
they've made it very difficult for ports
to automate even partially. uh and we
have we're nowhere near a fully
automated uh port system. And so Brett,
do Americans need to be concerned like
should we feel like we're falling behind
um in the AI race, the automation race,
in the global supply chain race? Do you
think that that these are places where
Americans are are falling behind? So 12
trillion US worth of goods go through
the Jebeli port as you said. That's 1.83
billion metric tons every year. and uh
over the next 5 years they predict that
they'll get to 80% um automation in in
that port. So that's the reality of
what's what's happening uh in on the
ground in uh the UAE. But as you've
rightly pointed out and as we've talked
about before, the dock workers strike
that occurred, you know, that tail end
of the Biden administration, one of the
key um, you know, concessions that were
made for the dock workers was an
agreement to not automate the ports for
another 20 years. How how is it possible
for the US to compete with China on the
belt and road with with infrastructure
without that level of automation in that
core infrastructure? Um you know the
it's it's not just about giving the
humans the job on jobs on on the docks.
It's about the level of efficiency and
the amount of cargo that can go through
the those ports in an autonomous uh you
know supply chain scenario. and China it
obviously let's look at electric
vehicles um they can now produce an
electric vehicle a new electric vehicle
in these dark factories in China every
seconds right and if you're going to be
producing that volume of new vehicles
and of course BYD just had their results
for um Q1 for Europe and they're out
selling Tesla uh you know and that's
just one of the EV manufacturers But
imagine that volume of vehicles going
through ports where it's still human
operated. You you would have a you know
um a bottleneck of course. So that
that's really um you know I think this
comes back to what we've discussed many
times about limits to growth and so
forth when you have this level of
automation and the way it can go. But
you know if you want to reduce the cost
of goods, if you want to be super
competitive, automation is going to be
an absolute key element of it. If the US
does want to onshore
um production facilities, they're going
to have to go with robotic, you know,
dark factories, right? Um otherwise it
won't be competitive from day one. The
labor cost alone would make it
uncompetitive. And if you're going to
have automated factories, you need to
have automated transportation supply
chain and automated shipping to uh to
round that out. I mean, that would seem
fairly logical. So, yeah, the the US has
some um problems with that. And the
tariffs won't fix that, right?
There there's a fiction here, this sort
of fallacy in the United States,
particularly in the manufacturing states
like Michigan, in the Midwest, where the
tariffs are somehow going to magically
revitalize American manufacturing. And
and this is just uh this is just not
true. This is just not the case. First
of all, the tariffs are going to make it
more expensive because we're going to
have to pay more for raw material coming
into the country. We don't have all the
resources here. Secondly, all we'd be
doing is protecting a very bloated and
inefficient um uh production facility
that can't compete on a global level.
So, yeah, we might build a tariff wall
around the country and that might mean
that Americans buy uh less good, you
know, inferior goods that are more
expensive, that won't help us win. And
in the long haul, the jobs won't stay
here. Even if we do create manufacturing
jobs, as you point out, all of this is
going to go to AI, dark factories,
automation. And so, you know what the
Chinese seem to be doing, and it looks
to me like the folks in the Middle East
are following this pattern. They're
saying, "Okay, what's the future look
like? Well, let's commit to that. Let's
invest everything we've got in building
out that future. Let's be the
friendliest to the future of any country
in the world and welcome all that
innovation." And here in the United
States, we seem to be going the opposite
way. We're trying to turn back the tide,
uh, turn back the hands of time and go
back to some mythical point in the past
where manufacturing was king and labor
was the was the queen. And honestly, I
just think that's a fiction. I don't see
I do not see how terrorists get us
there.
Well, on their own they can't. I mean,
that's uh that's key and and you know,
obviously we have had a um a deal done
between China and the US since uh uh
since we started talking about the
tariffs, but um and there have been 30%.
I mean, they're still quite high, right?
The tariffs. So, so they're not gone.
Like people think, oh, the tariffs are
over. No, 30% is ridiculous. it's going
to crush the earnings at Walmart among
other places
and China is not necessarily hurting.
You know, they've um in the in the midst
of all of this, I don't know whether you
saw and I know we got to go to a break
any minute, but um did you see the
Brazilia China trade deal that they did
a about a month and a half ago? So
massive you know and and keep in mind
you know brick the bricks economies of
the bricks economies Brazil, India and
China are expected to be four of the top
you know in the top five economies of
the world um you know within within the
next decade. And so Brazil and China did
this massive trade deal but the trade
deal was to be done excluding US dollar
trade. That was the basis of the deal.
We're talking um you know um uh I I
can't remember the size of the deal
right now, but specifically you know uh
circumventing uh the US dollar trading
markets. Yes. So that's that's
resistance against the Americans uh over
reliance on sanctions as a way to kind
of discipline other countries or get
them to conform with our wishes. We've
been relying on sanctions now for 30
years uh to manipulate countries and
it's only natural that trading partners
would say gosh maybe we don't want to
subject all of our transactions to uh
the US dollar and to the swift um to the
swift banking system. They can build a
system that works outside of that. It's
no secret that China's been focused on
trying to do that for some time. We'll
watch that. We'll continue to report on
it. Uh Brazil always has had a strong
relationship with China and the United
States. Those are the top two trading
partners for that country. And then none
of this just that trade with the United
States is going down, but terrorists are
not going to help that at all. We're
driving people into the embrace of other
countries. You know, it's it's very
true. And you know, um, China's
obviously concerned about if they do
take action in Taiwan, for example, the
potential for sanctions with US dollar.
Um, so what is the solution to that?
Well, they've created an alternative to
the Swift network. It's called SIPs. I
don't know if you've heard of it. It's
the crossber interbank payment system.
And this is uh you know for transactions
in Chinese one and it is uh you can run
the ECMY um you know the central bank
digital currency on it as well. But this
is specifically part of their strategy.
So they've been selling US Treasury
bills, buying up gold. They've got an
alternative to the Swift network for
payments and they're starting to do
major trade deals avoiding US dollar
currency. They they are clearly on a
longerterm strategy to reduce the risk
of uh US dollar sanctions and US dollar
banking system issues in the future. On
that sunny note, let's go to a break.
Hang on, folks, because we're going to
come back after one
minute. Okay, we're back. It's the
futurist with Rob Tersik and Brett King
and we're talking about global trade uh
the big announcement in Dubai of
building a a worldclass data center and
how that might uh impact their ability
to maintain the high levels of trade
that they have and uh and their seapport
uh their the the great number of
containers going through their seapport.
But what Brett just ended with before
the break is uh this ominous notion, I
think ominous from the US standpoint,
that China is building an alternative
payment system and a a trade system that
would not be subject or not as easily
subject to US sanctions and control. Uh
so that's a that's a strategic defense.
Sometimes I wonder, Brett, if the United
States thinks in 20-year terms the way
the Chinese tend to, you know, whether
we have a vision for 25 years out. Often
we ask our guests on the show, what's
your vision for 25 years? And you've
seen half the people have a vision, half
them don't. Right? And I think countries
are like that as well. Some countries
have a 25 year vision. Clearly Saudi
Arabia, clearly the UAE have a vision.
They know what they need to get done.
They have to, you know, transition off
of oil. They want to be leaders in the
information space. They're working hard
to get there. They're making the
investments. When you look at the United
States, though, it's a little bit tricky
for me to say like exactly what the
United States plan for 25 years out is,
if there is one. And the same could be
said for some European countries as
well.
I mean, it's impossible to do that in
the US political environment because if
you do start a 20-year plan, then what
could happen is the next administration
comes along and and you know puts a
bullet in it, right?
Soically now in a hyper problem, right?
Yep. On the other hand, like you to uh
let me offer a counterpoint here. So um
right now the US is considering uh the
Genius Act which would make stable coins
um a regulated digital currency and uh
and on the face of it actually it seems
to make sense. You know our previous
administrations had banned crypto they'
criminalized many of it uh many of the
activities and driven them offshore uh
and they had lawsuits against many
crypto companies our our securities and
exchange commission and we were treating
cryptos like any other security. So they
were relatively heavily taxed and as a
result there was very little innovation
happening on shore in the United States.
It was happening elsewhere. The goal
with the Genius Act is to reonshore that
and to do it um specifically with regard
to stable coins and of course the stable
coins would have to be pegged to
something and the US regulations would
require it to be pegged to American
assets uh treasury bills or dollar
assets. Uh and so there's you know a net
effort here I think to establish uh the
US dollar as a kind of reserve. That's
right. Well I think that's the It's the
only move. If if US is not going to do a
central bank digital currency, which is
sort of politically untenable, right? If
the US isn't going to launch a digital
dollar, then why not launch now? Why not
make this a haven for stable coins and
regulate them and make the dollar the
the default um payment, the default
security payment? I think it's an
interesting notion. I don't know. It's a
uh we'll see how that fares. There's
some resistance to it, but it looks like
that bill is gathering steam in Congress
right now. I know it's been debate
debated lively in a lively way in
Senate. Um and and in a way, you know,
that might be the free market
alternative to a central bank uh uh the
the highly centralized approach that the
Chinese have had. Sure. That would be a
good contrast, I think, uh for for the
US to do that. So, we'll we'll see. It
freaks out some people because crypto's
association with um you know frankly the
dark economy and uh and the number huge
number of scams and scandals has cast a
kind of uh you know appall of uh
incredul over the whole the whole space
but but that doesn't
uh if you focus on the scandals and the
scams you may not see the potential and
my thinking is that you're going to
start to see automation uh
require we're going to require stable
coins for machines. You can't Yeah, you
can't you can't run these smart
contracts on fiat currency. You can't
run these smart contracts on core
banking systems, right? You know, it's
why players like Stripe look so good
right now. I don't know whether you saw
the news uh last week, but was it last
week or the week before Stripe announced
um a stable coin uh current account,
right, in 100 countries overnight. Oh,
wow. and they have a really cool smart
contracting marketplace that they've
built. So, you know, um I mean JP Morgan
Chase is working on uh you know, some
stable coin uh stuff for trade finance.
HSBC has, but no one in the traditional
banking system has created a stable coin
marketplace like this for smart
contracts because it was seen as crypto
and DeFi and there wasn't supporting
regulation for that. now that there has
to be supporting regulation for stable
coins in order to do autonomous business
stuff because we're not going to do
CBDC's then you know you've got players
like Stripe who start you sort of were
one foot in the DeFi world and one foot
in the trady world are now looking like
next generation core infrastructure for
financial services and you know you you
know there's a you know let's think
about the US banking system right now
most of uh bank-to-bank uh uh commerce
in the U banktobank payments are still
done on the AC system uh the the the
automated clearing house but it's not
it's not real time that's why we had uh
the Fed now initiative which is the real
time initiative only about 10% of the
banks in the US are on Fed now today you
go to Brazil or you go to India or you
go to China and 100% of the banks are on
real-time payments rails and so you know
if you want to do autonomous business,
you need tokenized or digital currency
or a CBDC and you need real-time payment
rails and you need regulation that is uh
you know defined in terms of sort of
digital currency and so um you know the
US you know has to has to get get on
board with that pretty quickly as does
Europe but Europe is working on
launching the digital euro in 2027. So
they at least have a have a plan for
that. But stable coins would appear to
be probably more of the model for the
western um economies.
The only issue with that is we may see
that CBDC's
um you know better um sort of structured
in terms of crossber trade because they
can be configured to work with trade
agreements whereas stable coins are
going to be like the US dollar sort of
an accepted currency that's independent
of that but it won't have as much uh
configurability um or programmability
But that's just in terms of sort of the
way um you know we we structure the
instruction set and things like that. Um
it'll be interesting to see what an
economy like like the UAE and Saudi does
with that. Are they going to go to
stable coins? You know, what does OPEC
do? You know, what's OPEC going to do in
terms of trading oil on an autonomous
basis? You know, um are they going to go
for stable coins? Is Saudi going to push
their own um you know, uh digital
currency? Um it'll be interesting to
sort of see how that develops as well.
Yeah, I think you're right about that.
And what this all seems like to me is a
merging between the digital world and
the physical world. We it's a topic
we've visited from time to time on the
show. Uh but in any case, it seems like
it's converging and happening faster.
The key takeaway for me from this
conversation is uh Americans need to
travel more. We need to get out more and
see how other countries are doing it.
Yeah, there was a time where if you
wanted to see the future, you came to
the US. But that time was in the 1990s.
You know, I I haven't felt that way for
a long time. Even when mobile first
started to take off at the time I was
working at Sony and I would go to Japan
pretty frequently and I'd be like, "Wow,
this is like a trip to the future." You
could see the mobile internet taking
shape uh month by month in Japan in the
late 1990s when it wasn't even a thing
